node.text: The fast-spreading #deltavariant is raising fresh health concerns even in places where Covid vaccination rates are high. Senior pharmaceuticals analyst Sam Fazeli is here to tell you what you need to know.

node.text:
"Donald Trump upended the American presidency after stepping away from the company that made him rich and famous. Four years later, returning to his empire after losing the White House, what he finds may upend him," write Sophie Alexander and Max Abelson.

"Three quarters of Trump's net worth is tied up in urban real estate. And urban real estate has been hammered by Covid-19," Tim O'Brien tells @quicktake's Tim Stenovec.

The former president's net worth is down to $2.3 billion from $3 billion in 2016. The pandemic he promised would disappear is walloping his company, and the riot that got him impeached for a second time is wounding his brand.

Check out "Trump’s Ailing Empire" on bloomberg.com/graphics to see just how deep in peril he really is.

node.text:
👻 Snap Inc. is rolling out a new tool for its Snapchat app to feature popular videos, called Spotlight, and said it will pay out $1 million a day to creators of the top-performing posts. How good of a deal is that?

🤳🏻 "The more remarkable thing about Snap is that it wasn't offering these sort of incentives to people to create good content previously."

Alex Webb joined @quicktake's Tim Steno to explain why Snap decided to compensate viral creators.

#snapchat #influencer #app #creators #snap

node.title: Snapchat to Pay $1 Million a Day to Creators

node.text:
It’s been 20 months since a pair of fatal crashes forced regulators around the globe to ground the once top-selling jet. The FAA finally approved the Max to resume commercial flights today, which will allow Boeing to make money off the roughly 450 Max jets it has built but not yet delivered.

After the longest grounding of an aircraft in modern U.S. history, it’s reasonable to ask whether the plane is safe. Bloomberg Opinion columnists Chris Bryant and Brooke Sutherland teamed up to discuss the future of the Max, and whether or not they'd be willing to board one.

#Boeing #Boeing737 #737max #airplane #aircraft #airline #southwest #americanair #flight #pandemic #livestream #video #igtv #travel

node.title: Boeing’s 737 Max Is Back. Are You Willing to Board?

node.text:
Frank Barry didn’t ask a soul about Donald Trump or Joe Biden on his @looking4lincoln trip. For the two months he spent crossing the country along the Lincoln Highway by Winnebago, talking with Americans and hoping to reach San Francisco by Election Day, he never brought up the campaign. Sometimes he knew how people felt — occasionally they would say, though usually not. But it didn’t matter. He wasn’t running a focus group. He was trying to catch glimpses of a more enduring spirit, the kind that has transcended parties and generations, the kind that lives, as Lincoln said, in the better angels of our nature. And maybe those glimpses could help us see more of ourselves in each other, and in the land we share.

#lincolnhighway #travel #rv #roadtrip #winnebago #highway #ontheroad #interview #video

node.title: The End of the Lincoln Highway

node.text:
Delta Airlines is going to be charging $200 a month to employees who choose not to get vaccinated, on the basis that this raises Delta's own insurance costs.

Scott Kominers explains that this corresponds with the classic economic idea of taxing people their "externality" – called Pigouvian taxation: If you charge people the amount their behavior increases costs for others, then they internalize that cost when they're making decisions.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 30, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Compensation in crypto is bound to raise red flags for the Internal Revenue Service. 

From professional athletes to tech employees, more people are getting paid, or wanting to be paid, in cryptocurrencies. They cite the ease and transparency of payments in digital currencies. 

But there are some important considerations to keep in mind. Aside from the volatility, a misstep could result in not getting compensated correctly. For U.S. employers and employees, sorting out the tax part alone is cumbersome at best.

The smartest approach for those interested in getting paid in digital currencies is usually a hybrid, with some compensation in cryptocurrencies and some in dollars, writes Alexis Leondis. For those more bullish on the future of digital currencies, it's better to just invest in them outright than gamble with your paycheck.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 30, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Vaccine passes to fly are thenextstep to boost trave 2021 Traveler Throughput 2020 2019 3M MWWWMM Jan 2021 Feb Mar Apr Source: Transportation May Jun Jul Aug BloomberaOpinion'.

node.text:
✈️ Covid shots for U.S. airline workers makes sense. But what would really help the industry’s bottom line is mandating vaccines or negative tests for passengers, writes Brooke Sutherland.

The highly transmissible delta variant is undermining a U.S. travel recovery that was just starting to show real momentum. That’s a contrast to Europe, where widespread adoption of health passes that show proof of vaccination, recovery from Covid-19 or a recent negative test is helping to bolster air-travel demand. 

57% of American adults support requiring vaccinations for air travel, according to a poll from the Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research.

Given the myriad complications and the industry’s role in interstate commerce, it’s unlikely the airlines will act of their own accord to require negative Covid tests or proof of vaccination to use their services. This is ultimately a government issue. 

The U.S.’s reluctance to enforce health checks for transportation increasingly puts it at odds with allies.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 29, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, suit and text.

node.text:
Thinking of getting a CFA? Get an MBA instead. The CFA program doesn’t really make you a better investor, and costs hundreds if not thousands of hours of your precious time, writes Jared Dillian.

“When I was studying for the exams, I wasn’t really learning the material; I was just learning how to pass a test. I honestly don’t remember a single thing I learned from the CFA program. On the other hand, I got a great deal out of my MBA program, which was an immersive experience, with in-person classes, guest lectures and study groups. My MBA is still paying dividends,” explains Dillian.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about why the CFA just isn’t worth it.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 29, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'It'sgetting alot busier at the Southwest border Monthly Southwest border apprehensions, U.S. Border Patrol 200K 150 100 50 1999 2010 Source:U.S. Customs and Border Protection 2020 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🇲🇽🇺🇸Things aren’t exactly settling down along the U.S. border with Mexico, with the U.S. Border Patrol reporting 178,416 apprehensions in the Southwest in June, its highest monthly total since early 2000.

What is driving all these people to the U.S.? The job prospects and pay for less-educated, lower-wage workers (which is what unauthorized immigrants often end up being, although their education levels have been rising) in the U.S. is on the rise, and America is in the midst of a period of economic outperformance relative to Mexico.

"With the U.S. experiencing one of the world’s strongest recoveries from the pandemic recession, it should be no surprise that it’s attracting lots of economic migrants from points south," writes Justin Fox.

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 28, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, standing, outdoors and text that says 'Is the post- Covid wedding boom ruining you financially? BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
Your early 30s can feel like a constant cycle of weddings and babies. Of course, these are joyous times, but they can also be stressful. If you feel like the engagement parties, bachelor(ette) parties, bridal showers, weddings, gender reveal parties and baby showers are starting to feel like a drain on your bank account, you're not alone.

35% of millennials went into debt just to attend bachelor and bachelorette parties. 20% said they’d gone into debt to attend weddings. And 33% said they wouldn’t feel comfortable declining if they couldn’t afford to attend.

As Erin Lowry writes, it's about to get worse. 2022 is set to host the most weddings since 1984. That means either our wallets are going to take a beating, or we have to learn how to have some tough conversations. Tap the link in our bio for advice on how to navigate that.

#wedding #weddingboom #henparty #stagparty #babyshower #genderreveal

node.text:
💄Delta variant or not, our wallets are now firmly focused on getting us out of the house.

Americans are folding up their sweatpants, putting away their mixing bowls and even reining in their enthusiasm for home improvements. Unless states introduce lockdowns again, it’s hard to see another headlong dive into those early pandemic purchases.

@andrea_felsted writes: “Even with the recent surge of delta variant cases, retailers haven’t reported a huge change in consumer preferences. Urban Outfitters said this week that the impact from delta was “negligible,” with August trends at most divisions in line with those of the second quarter. Walmart and Target both said the back-to-school season also had a strong start.”

Looks like Americans just don’t want to go back to the dark days of pandemic baking and shed building. That said, there are a couple of key areas that delta is impacting. Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 28, 2021. May be an image of 2 people, people sitting and text that says 'The world cannot abandon Afghanistan's schoolgirls BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The greatest single achievement in Afghanistan in the last 20 years is probably the meteoric expansion of education from 1 million to 9.5 million students. Now that risks being reversed by the Taliban.

At the peak, 65% of young girls were attending first grade and 4 million more girls were benefiting from primary or secondary education. Many were training to be doctors, scientists and lawyers, and entering professional occupations for the first time.

"Any new Taliban-led government needs to understand that the eyes of the world are upon it," Gordon Brown writes. "We should state unequivocally that aid, including the donor pledges already made for 2021-2024, will be withdrawn if the rights of girls are not upheld."

Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.text:
The pandemic took away opportunities for many of the things that Americans do to de-stress, relax and take care of themselves. Census time-use surveys found fewer hours spent on things like travel, shopping and even personal grooming.

All of this took its toll. Depression diagnoses soared, as did many other indicators of stress.

"Covid, however, wasn’t the only stressor weighing on Americans’ minds. Summer 2020 saw the largest protests in American history, along with widespread looting and other forms of social unrest," writes Noah Smith.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about why politics and the pandemic combined to produce unprecedented levels of anxiety and depression at the end of 2020.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 27, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'Here's why you should consider switching from Apple to Android BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The world’s best-selling smartphone may not be tops when it comes to navigating life during a global pandemic. At least that’s what Tae Kim discovered — and it’s why he ditched his iPhone.

For starters, iPhone owners all know masks and the iPhone’s FaceID face-reading technology do not mix. In contrast, the Samsung Galaxy’s S21 Ultra’s fingerprint reader is extremely convenient, explains Kim.

That’s not the only reason Kim made the switch which he calls a “dramatic upgrade.” Tap the link in our bio to read more.

#apple #android #iphone #samsunggalaxy #smartphone #tech

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 26, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'Americans are splashing out on boats like never before U.S. consumer spending on pleasure boats $25B 20 15 10 2010 2012 2014 SoUS.A Bureau Economic 2016 2018 2020 BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
🚤 As soon as Americans began emerging from their homes after the first wave of Covid-19 in spring 2020, many apparently headed straight to their local boat dealers. Spending on pleasure boats shot up to 20% in May 2020 above the pre-pandemic pace. So far this year, boat spending is running nearly 50% higher than before the pandemic.

Justin Fox isn't surprised: "At a time when crowded indoor spaces can pose deadly risks, small boats (not cruise ships!) are pretty great places to be. The remote-work arrangements forced by the pandemic have also made it easier for affluent white-collar workers to locate themselves within convenient distance of a body of water."

So what sort of boats are people buying? And who's buying them? Tap the link in our bio to read more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Opinion on August 26, 2021. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, road and text that says 'America's future looks alotlike like lot Florida: old, Southern andretired BloombergOpinion'.

node.text:
The fastest growing metro area in the U.S. is the Villages, a retirement community in Florida. That says a lot about the U.S. of the future.

This shouldn't be surprising, as Americans are getting older. But the fact that a retirement community is the fastest-growing city is significant. Allison Schrager writes: "In the last decade, retirees have emerged as the fastest growing category of movers...This signifies an economy where there’s more growth coming from people who are moving to end their career rather than advance it. That comes with implications for our politics."

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the political implications of an old, Southern, retired America.

#florida
